description.narrative: Strengthen PA management in Sulawesi and reduce threats to biodiversity in the PAs by putting in place measures ensuring that the highly unique and globally important biodiversity safeguarded from on-going threats.
seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: BOGANI NANI WARTABONE NATIONAL PARK (287,115 ha): The PA is the largest terrestrial national park in Sulawesi and has 24 species of mammal, 125 species of bird, 11 species of reptile, 2 species of amphibian, 38 species of butterfly, 200 species of beetle and 19 species of fish. A species endemic to

GREATER TANGKOKO CONSERVATION AREA (8,665 ha): The area is made up of several protected areas and surrounding landscape, including nature reserves, protection forests and recreation forests. The landscape is significant due to the support it provides for high densities of some of Sulawesi’s most ico

description.narrative: seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: LORE LINDU NATIONAL PARK (217,992 ha): The PA is the 2nd largest terrestrial national park in Sulawesi and contains a good representation of the island’s unique biota and harbours numerous rare species, including 77 bird species endemic to Sulawesi. 40 species of mammals have been recorded, 31 of wh

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1. Institutional capacity scores based on UNDP Capacity development score card for: (I) DG of KSDAE; (ii) Lore Lindu NP; (iii) Boganinani Wartabone; (iv) North Sulawesi BKSDA. 2. Annual levels of deforestation within Sulawesi’s terrestrial protected areas (PAs).

comment.narrative: 1. Institutional capacity scores for DG of KSDAE (66%); LLNP (43%); Boganinani NP (42%); North Sulawesi BKSDA (40%). 2. Approximately 56,505 ha of forest loss within PAs from 2000-2008 or 7,603 ha/year.

1. Using PHKA RBM scoring system, at least 50% of resorts in the project sites have achieved at least one stage level above the baseline. 2. Intelligence-based anti-poaching has become a well-known feature of PA management, affecting incentives in measurable ways (surveys). 3. Users across Sulawesi, Indonesia and beyond are able to upload to and access historic data on biodiversity and protected areas, generated by multiple sources, using a platform created by the project. 4. 210,000 ha, or 6.7% of remaining habitat type, representing a 60% increase in coverage. 5. Financial sustainable score: a. Component 1: 50% b. Component 2: 50% c. Component 3: 50% 6. 25% increase, to $16.81 million. 7. At least two new sustainable financing mechanisms for PA management established, providing a minimum of US$ 3 million per year for PA management. 8. METT Score: LLNP (70); BNWNP (70); Tangkoko Batuangas NR (70). 9. Threat indices: LLNP (0.15); BNWNP (0.20); Tangkoko Batuangas NR (0.20). 10. EHI: LLNP (0.75); BNWNP (0.75); Tangkoko Batuangas NR (0.75). 11. Population of selected species: indicator population species maintained or increasing; appropriate population structure. 12. Zero increase in net levels of active encroachment. 13. Collaborative governance system: a. At least 45 CCAs, including some at each project demonstration site. b. 80% of above CCAs are operating at an agreed baseline level of functionality. c. 40% of above CCAs are rated as ‘highly functional’.

In Sulawesi ,community has been engaged the management and PAs system. UNDP Facilitated 10 farmer groups to receive small grants for their alternative livelihood development..The National Park sowed more than 4000 seeds to conserve biodiversity. Local regulation on illegal wildlife trades has been developed for target PAs in Sulawesi. In Sulawesi, the community has been engaged in the management and PAs system. The UNDP has facilitated 10 farmer groups to receive small grants for their alternative livelihood development. The National Park planted more than 4000 seeds to conserve biodiversity. Local regulation on illegal wildlife trade has been developed for target PAs in Sulawesi. As regards to CapDev index, between the years of 2018 to 2020, it was 72% for BNW NP; 68% for Tangkoko Batuangas NR; and 67% for LL NP. The area degraded was 1020.18 in LL NP in the year 2019. As regards to the 3rd Indicator (the expansion of RBM implementation): The RBM in BNW NP has been implemented in 11 Resorts (100%) and has improved 1-2 levels since 2016; RBM in Tangkoko Batuangas NR has been implemented in 2 Resorts (100%) and has improved to level 6 since the year 2016; The RBM in LL NP has been implemented in 3 Resorts: Resort Simoro (baseline level 4), Resort Doda (level 4) Resort Toro (level 5) based on assesment by the WCS in the year 2016. Right now the RBM in those Resorts mentioned has improved 1-2 level from the baseline of 2016. As regards to the 4th Indicator, the progress has been achieved that the reporting system for wildlife trade and consumption in the project site and the buffer zone has been implemented. As regards to the 5th Indicator, the progress has been achieved that for the budgeting, planning, and monitoring the island-based biodiversity has been implemented. As regards to the 6th Indicator, the progress has been achieved that the EPASS project has facilitated some activities in developing the Gandang Dewata National Park up to the issuance of Minister of Environment and Forestrys Decision Letter (SK Menteri LHK (SK No.773 dated October 3rd 2016 on designating Gandang Dewata NP covering 79,342 ha area in West Sulawesi. As regards to the 7th Indicator: During the course of the project, Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has compiled studies related to regulations and policies needed to enable revenue streams to conservation areas from non-government funding sources. Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has also established the economic valuation for the three priority locations. In 2020, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is developing a digital platform to increase the public awareness on the importance of the financing for conservation areas and biodiversity conservation. Through this Component 2.1, the Ministry of PPN/Bapepnas is pushing for policy changes at the national level to support an increase in the value of the financial sustainability scorecard. Some of the efforts that have been achieved are: (1) elevating the discourse of integration of sustainable funding options for conservation areas, including the establishment of a BLU for national parks, (2) mainstreaming conservation issues into national priorities that have implications for increasing the allocation of conservation area funding, and (3) encouraging the use of planning and funding systems in mainstreaming conservation issues. Utilization of the planning and budgeting system that was encouraged during the past three years is Planning and Information Performance Collaboration Information System (KRISNA), which is managed jointly between Ministry of PPN/Bappenas, Ministry of Finance, and Ministry of PAN RB. The existence of the KRISNA information system enables information disclosure in planning and budgeting, good documentation during the planning and implementation of activities, and monitoring and evaluation of performance and budget information for each ministry/institution. In 2020, Ministry of PPN/Bappenas with MoEF will reassess the financial sustainability scorecard to see if the target of 50% for each component has been achieved. As regards to the 8th Indicator: In 2019, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has completed a business plan for the Bogani Nani Wartabone National Park. The Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has updated the business plan this year by focusing on the developing sustainable institutional for financing including its financial projection for the trust fund management. In 2020, The Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is conducting a pilot project for sustainable financing implementation in TNBNW, focusing on the brown sugar financing mechanism through the concept of agroforestry. The end expected result is the formulation of conservation partnership agreement in the BNW landscape: park management, agroforestry community group, and Forest Management Units. The ministry of PPN/Bappenas will also formulate a protocol of lessons learned from the pilot project implementation as a reference for future replications. Meanwhile, the business plan for KPHK Tangkoko and Lore Lindu National Park (TNLL) are under formulation. The formulation of strategies for financing includes: (1) analysis of current financial and budget, as well as the funding needs to achieve optimistic target for protected area management, (2) identification of potential business opportunities to contribute in protected area management system, and (3) strategies to implementing business models for protected areas. Until July 2020, data and information have been collected from various stakeholders namely the National Parks Management and its partners. The process has been showing slow progress due to the COVID-19 pandemic that limits physical gatherings and journeys to project’s landscapes. Prior to project intervention, each project priority landscape did not have a clear business plan for activities and funding. The development of the business plan is useful to: (1) understand the existing conditions of costs and funding as well as the gaps in each landscape, (2) understand the effectiveness of the use of costs that have been implemented so far, and (3) identify alternative sources of funding available to support sustainable management in the area. Beneficiaries of this business plan include the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas, Directorate General of the KSDAE and National Park entity in Ministry of Environment and Forestry, partners from each priority landscape, and academics/researchers. Budget increased was calculated based on the government budget allocation in Sulawesi landscape, comprises of RM (rupiah murni/domestic revenue), PNBP (Pendapatan Negara Bukan Pajak/Non-Tax Revenue), SBSN (Surat Berharga Syariah Negara/Islamic Bond), HLN (Hibah luar negeri/foreign grant) through the UPT DIPA. The annual budget allocation data has showed an increase of 35% from year 2015 to year 2020. In 2020, the use of government budgets sourced from RM and PNBP is focused on (1) conflict resolution in conservation forests, (2) collaborative management of conservation forests, (3) productive economic activities with the community, (4) effectiveness of conservation forest management, (5) conservation areas verification for biodiversity protection, and (6) ecotourism development. Furthermore, the budget allocation in the year of 2020 is Rp265 billion or equivalent to USD18.9 million. To conclude, the target of the project document to increase the budget allocation by 25% or equivalent to USD15 million has been achieved. From the results of project implementation, including learning from the preparation of business plans, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has raised various funding mechanisms and strategies to national policy level both in the 2015-2019 RPJMN and in the 2020-2024 RPJMN, namely: (1) preparation RPJMN 2020-2024 coordinated by Bappenas, (2) assistance to Directorate General of Natural Resources and Ecosystem Conservation, Ministry of Environment and Forestry in accessing funding through the mechanism of Islamic Bond (SBSN), (3) assistance to Directorate General of Natural Resources and Ecosystem Conservation, The Ministry of Environment and Forestry in preparing annual work and financing plans, (4) increasing staff capacity in terms of planning and budgeting for management of conservation areas and (5) carrying out various forum / workshop/seminar activities to build sustainable funding mechanisms for the management of conservation areas. As regards to the 9th Indicator: The Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has completed a review of regulation framework to support the financing mechanism. A proposed financing model for each project priority landscape has also been finalized. In addition to that, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has formulated the design of Sustainable Financing Mechanism for Conservation Areas. The design has been publicly consulted and suggesting the institutional arrangement in conservation forest to achieve the sustainable financing. In 2020, The Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is aiming to increase the effectiveness of sustainable financing through broader socialization. The methodology that is deployed is ADKAR (appreciation, desire, knowledge, ability, and reinforcement) for three mechanisms: SBSN, BLU (Badan Layanan Umum/Public Services Agency), and Trust Fund. Bappenas is actively encouraging the use of SBSN instruments so that it can finance the development of ecotourism infrastructure and wildlife breeding in conservation areas. The Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has also raised the issue of ecotourism development and protection of endangered animals into national priority projects so as to get increased budget allocations for both issues. This is indicated by the many outputs of National Park Management activities that become national priority outputs. Furthermore, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is currently examining the role/contribution of conservation as well as the Islamic bond for conservation to the national priorities that could provide at least USD 3 million per year for conservation areas and biodiversity management in Sulawesi. The roles of conservation has been reflected in the annual government work plan (Rencana Kerja Pemerintah/RKP) and the mid term national development plan (RPJMN). As regards to the 10th Indicator: the METT value has increased in all project sites: 1) 77% in BNW NP; 2) 68% in Tangkoko Batuputih NR; 61% in Tangkoko Batuangus NR; 62% in Tangkoko Duasudara NR; 3) 73% in LL NP. As regards to the 11th Indicator: Threat Index was 31% in BNW NP; 18% in Tangkoko NR; and 18% in LL NP. As regards to the 12th Indicator: The value of Environmental Health Indicator reached 66% in BNW NP, 78% in Tangkoko NR, and 66% in LL NP. As regards to the 13th Indicator: In BNW NP: 1) the occupancy rate based on trap camera for the anoa and deer-pig subsequently is 32% and 36%; 2) The occupancy rate of the maleo birds couple in 3 locations throughout the years of 2016-2019, has significantly increased from 6.4% to 54.4%. In the Tangkoko Batuangas NR: 1) The Yaki SRAK document has been legalized in the year 2019; 2) Based on the monitoring and evaluation conducted in year 2019, four locations of active spawning of maleo birds have been found; 3) There has been found that the population density of Yaki reached 14.6 Yakis/km2 based on the survey done in 2019. In the area of LL NP: 1) In the year 2019 in the Cluster of CS-25 were found the rate of encounter with the anoa was 40 times; 2) In Q2 of year 2020 it is planned to conduct survey on the anoa in the Clusters of CS-18 and CS-5. As regards to the 14th Indicator: In BNW NP: 1) Joint area patrol by the community through RBM mechanism and Smart Patrol have been done in 11 resorts; 2) It has been stated in the CCA agreement by 17 groups in 15 villages to refrain from any encroaching activities; 3)Re-planting activities have been implemented by CCA groups with conservation partnership for ecosystem recovery. In Tangkoko NR: 1) With the support of the EPASS project, all of the CCAs have agreed to refrain from encroaching activities; 2) Awareness raising regarding border boundary has been conducted in the buffer zone of Tangkoko NR; 3) Planting on the border line has been done by CCA Madidir & Winesa; 4) Replanting the open areas has been done together with the local natural resources conservation agency (BKSDA) and the partners. In LL NP: 1) SMART Patrol has been conducted; 2) Has supported the recovery of the Dongi Dongi ecosystem; 3) Establishment of village conservation management unit, for which part of the activities is conducting joint patrol with the community of the National Park; 4)Reduce any activities related to encroachment by planting non-timber forest products in the traditional zones, Planting living boundary together with the CCAs of Doda Village and Lempe Village. As regards to the 15th Indicator: Until Q2 of year 2020, there have been 46 agreement documents signed out of the 46 documents proposed. The funds has been disbursed in the amount of IDR3,345,813,124 for 42 signed documents, out of the total value for 46 documents in the amount of IDR6,227,218,648.

1) 2020: Capacity score for PHKA/ KSDAE (Jakarta): 75%, LLNP: 55%, Bogani Nani NP: 55% and North Sulawesi BKSDA: 55%; 2) 2020: 25% reduction in annual deforestation within PAs and buffer zones in the project sites combined between baseline years (2000-2010) and last three years of project (2016-2019); 3) 2020: Using PHKA RBM scoring system (para 60), at least 50% of resorts in the project sites achieved one stage level above the baseline; 4) 2020: Intelligence-based anti-poaching has become a well-known feature of PA management, affecting incentives in measurable ways (surveys); 5) 2020: Users across Sulawesi, Indonesia and beyond are able to upload to and access historic data on biodiversity and protected areas, generated by multiple sources, using a platform created by the project; 6) 2020: Representation of low land forest increased to 210,000 ha, or 6.7% of remaining habitat type (representing a 60% increase in coverage); 7) 2020: Increased financial sustainability score for component 1 (50%), component 2 (50%) and component 3 (50%); 8) 2020: Annual budget allocation to the PA system increased 25% equivalent to approx. $15 million; 9) 2020: At least two new sustainable financing mechanisms for PA management developed, which can provide a minimum of US$ 3 million per year for PA management; 10) 2020: Increased METT Score for LLNP – 70, BNWNP – 70, and Tangkoko Batuangas NR – 70; 11) 2020: Reduced threat indices for LLNP – 0.15; BNWNP – 0.20; Tangkoko Batuangas NR – 0.20; 12) 2020: Increased EHI for Lore Lindu NP - .75; Bogani Nani Wartabone NP - .75; Tangkoko Batuangas NR - .75; 13) 2020: Indicator population species maintained or increasing; appropriate population structure achieved; 14) 2020: Zero increase in net levels of active encroachment; 15) 2020: (i) At least 45 CCAs, including some at each project demonstration site; (ii) 70% of above CCAs are operating at an agreed baseline level of functionality; (iii) 35% of above CCAs are rated as ‘highly functional’ (rating system to be developed and applied during inception phase).

Overall progress to date is 54.6%.(LLNP), 56.3% (Bogani Nani NP), 56% (North Sulawesi BKSDA). The activity is to measure progress for this indicator is planned for this year 2020. The progress for the specific targets: LLNP: 67% ; Bogani Nani NP: 72% ; North Sulawesi BKSDA: 68%
In Sulawesi, the community has been engaged in the management and PAs system. The UNDP has facilitated 10 farmer groups to receive small grants for their alternative livelihood development. The National Park planted more than 4000 seeds to conserve biodiversity. Local regulation on illegal wildlife trade has been developed for target PAs in Sulawesi. As regards to CapDev index, between the years of 2018 to 2020, it was 72% for BNW NP; 68% for Tangkoko Batuangas NR; and 67% for LL NP.
There has been significant improvement with the support of EPASS. The local management authorities are now more confident to collect data, to maintain data, and to actualize for each region, as informed in the EPASS and the FCU reports. The area degraded was 1020.18 in LL NP in the year 2019.
It is monitored annually with satellite imagery. EPASS has engaged the stakeholders to do tree planting, and has conducted awareness-raising for the stakeholders to include the environmental conservation as part of the priority activities.
The project hasnt estimated and calculated the reduction in annual forest carbon emissions in this reporting period yet. Implementation of these activities will be conducted in the year 2020.
This indicator has been achieved and End of Project target exceeded.
As regards to the 3rd Indicator (the expansion of RBM implementation): The RBM in BNW NP has been implemented in 11 Resorts (100%) and has improved 1-2 levels since 2016; RBM in Tangkoko Batuangas NR has been implemented in 2 Resorts (100%) and has improved to level 6 since the year 2016; The RBM in LL NP has been implemented in 3 Resorts: Resort Simoro (baseline level 4), Resort Doda (level 4) Resort Toro (level 5) based on assesment by the WCS in the year 2016. Right now the RBM in those Resorts mentioned has improved 1-2 level from the baseline of 2016.
Baseline for this Indicator was zero. With the support from EPASS, and with the RBM, the local stakeholders have become more and more familiar with the GPS. As part of the results, nowadays the Resort staff are able to provide better quality of information. They are now able to mention in which exact Grid, in which Nesting Ground, and in which coordinates, when they are given the questions. Right now, the RBM in Tangkoko Nature Reserve for instance, has reached level 6. They have reached 100% from the target of 50%.
As regards to the 4th Indicator, the progress has been achieved that the reporting system for wildlife trade and consumption in the project site and the buffer zone has been implemented.
In BNW NP, the activities include: 1) Distribution map of wildlife trade; 2) List of wildlife traded; and 3) Monthly routine patrol. As regards to the 5th Indicator, the progress has been achieved that for the budgeting, planning, and monitoring the island-based biodiversity has been implemented.
As regards to the 6th Indicator, the progress has been achieved that the EPASS project has facilitated some activities in developing the Gandang Dewata National Park up to the issuance of Minister of Environment and Forestrys Decision Letter (SK Menteri LHK (SK No.773 dated October 3rd 2016 on designating Gandang Dewata NP covering 79,342 ha area in West Sulawesi.
This indicator will be removed from the final project document according to board meeting results. However, the project has to inform RTA or relevant focal points in BRH to remove this indicator/target from the RF-based on feedback from inception workshop and subsequent approval from PB. Source: Activity Report .
There are 3 (three) main components reviewed in the Financial Sustainability Score Card, namely (1) regulatory and institutional frameworks, (2) business models to support effective management, and (3) revenue generating schemes. The financial score card targets determined at the end of the project is 50% for component 1, 50% for component 2, and 50% for component 3. With the project intervention, in 2019, the financial score has reached 57% for component 1, 49% for component 2, and 46% for component 3 (Ev5). It is only 1% away from EOP target for component 2, and 4% away for component 3.
Through this Component 2.1, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is pushing for policy changes at the national level to support an increase in the value of the financial sustainability scorecard. Some of the efforts that have been achieved are: (1) elevating the discourse of integration of sustainable funding options for conservation areas, including the establishment of a BLU for national parks, (2) mainstreaming conservation issues into national priorities that have implications for increasing the allocation of conservation area funding, and (3) encouraging the use of planning and funding systems in mainstreaming conservation issues.
Utilization of the planning and budgeting system that was encouraged during the past three years is Planning and Information Performance Collaboration Information System (KRISNA), which is managed jointly between Ministry of PPN/Bappenas, Ministry of Finance, and Ministry of PAN RB. The existence of the KRISNA information system enables information disclosure in planning and budgeting, good documentation during the planning and implementation of activities, and monitoring and evaluation of performance and budget information for each ministry/institution.
Beneficiaries of sustainability scorecard assessment are Ministry of PPN/Bappenas, Ministry of Environment and Forestry, development partner (specifically UNDP) and partners from each priority landscape. Using this scorecard, all parties can identify essential aspects of protected area financing system in Indonesia and can assess where the improvement needs to be made.
During the project, Ministry of PPN/Bappenas compiled studies related to regulations and policies needed to enable revenue streams to conservation areas from non-government funding sources. Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has also established the economic valuation for the three priority locations (Ev6). TN Bogani Nani Wartabone has valuation of USD 136/ha/year, TN Lore Lindu is USD 158/ha/year, while KPHK Tangkoko is USD 1,760/ha/year. In TN Bogani Nani Wartabone and TN Lore Lindu, watershed protection services are particular value, while tourism makes a major economic contribution in KPHHK Tangkoko. With the existence of this valuation study, it is clear that TN Bogani Nani Wartabone, TN Lore Lindu and KPHK Tangkoko are able to generate substantial economic benefits for a wide range of stakeholders and many group can have benefit from protected areas. For protected area managers, this valuation study can open opportunities to initiate partnership with related stakeholders.
Further, in 2020, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is developing a digital platform to increase the public awareness on the importance of the financing for protected areas and biodiversity conservation.
To conclude, component 2.1 is approximately 90% against EOP target. In 2020, Ministry of PPN/Bappenas with Ministry of Environment and Forestry will reassess the financial sustainability scorecard to see if the target of 50% for each component has been achieved. Target of the project document to increase the budget allocation by 25% or equivalent to USD16.81 million has been achieved.
Budget increased was calculated based on the government budget allocation in Sulawesi landscape, comprises of RM (rupiah murni/domestic revenue), PNBP (Pendapatan Negara Bukan Pajak/Non-Tax Revenue), SBSN (Surat Berharga Syariah Negara/Islamic Bond), HLN (Hibah luar negeri/foreign grant) through the UPT DIPA. The annual budget allocation data has showed an increase of 35% from year 2015 to year 2020. In 2020, the use of government budgets sourced from RM and PNBP is focused on (1) conflict resolution in conservation forests, (2) collaborative management of conservation forests, (3) productive economic activities with the community, (4) effectiveness of conservation forest management, (5) conservation areas verification for biodiversity protection, and (6) ecotourism development. Furthermore, the budget allocation in the year of 2020 is Rp265 billion or equivalent to USD18.9 million (Ev12).
In 2019, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has completed a business plan for the Bogani Nani Wartabone National Park (Ev3, Ev7). The Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has updated the business plan this year by focusing on the developing sustainable institutional for financing including its financial projection for the trust fund management (Ev8). In 2020, The Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is conducting a pilot project for sustainable financing implementation in TNBNW, focusing on the brown sugar financing mechanism through the concept of agroforestry. The end expected result is the formulation of conservation partnership agreement in the BNW landscape: park management, agroforestry community group, and Forest Management Units (Ev9). The ministry of PPN/Bappenas will also formulate a protocol of lessons learned from the pilot project implementation as a reference for future replications.
Meanwhile, the business plan for KPHK Tangkoko and Lore Lindu National Park (TNLL) are under formulation (Ev10, Ev11). The formulation of strategies for financing includes: (1) analysis of current financial and budget, as well as the funding needs to achieve optimistic target for protected area management, (2) identification of potential business opportunities to contribute in protected area management system, and (3) strategies to implementing business models for protected areas. Until July 2020, data and information have been collected from various stakeholders namely the National Parks Management and its partners. The process has been showing slow progress due to the COVID-19 pandemic that limits physical gatherings and journeys to project’s landscapes.
Prior to project intervention, each project priority landscape did not have a clear business plan for activities and funding. The development of the business plan is useful to: (1) understand the existing conditions of costs and funding as well as the gaps in each landscape, (2) understand the effectiveness of the use of costs that have been implemented so far, and (3) identify alternative sources of funding available to support sustainable management in the area. Beneficiaries of this business plan include the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas, Directorate General of the KSDAE and National Park entity in Ministry of Environment and Forestry, partners from each priority landscape, and academics/researchers.
For government, the business plan can be a scientific basis for short, medium, and long-term planning and budgeting system. For development partner, the business plan is a valid reference to synchronize and integrate the program and activities in priority landscape. For academics/researchers, the business plan can be a reference to calculate the effectiveness of protected area financing, as well as be a model for further replication in another landscapes. In landscape level, the benefit for national park manager is to have reference for more effective planning and budgeting system, with consideration of gap analysis and potential funding source. In national level, the business plan can be a model for Ministry of PPN/Bappenas in mainstreaming the protected areas issue into the national priority.
From the results of project implementation, including learning from the preparation of business plans, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has raised various funding mechanisms and strategies to national policy level both in the 2015-2019 RPJMN and in the 2020-2024 RPJMN, namely: (1) preparation RPJMN 2020-2024 coordinated by Ministry of PPN/Bappenas, (2) assistance to Directorate General of Natural Resources and Ecosystem Conservation, Ministry of Environment and Forestry in accessing funding through the mechanism of Islamic Bond (SBSN), (3) assistance to Directorate General of Natural Resources and Ecosystem Conservation, The Ministry of Environment and Forestry in preparing annual work and financing plans, (4) increasing staff capacity in terms of planning and budgeting for management of conservation areas and (5) carrying out various forum / workshop/seminar activities to build sustainable funding mechanisms for the management of conservation areas.
There are several activities that has been delayed due to Covid19, such as the development of business plan in TN Lore Lindu and KPHK Tangkoko. The limitation of physical gathering and travelling causes all meetings and FGDs being done by online and it limits the dynamicity of discussion. The secondary data needed for basis of business plan development is harder to gather and cause a significant delay of analysis. The primary data that initially needs to be gathered through field visit has not been collected as well.
The major impact of Covid19 is felt to implementation of sustainable financing mechanism in TN Bogani Nani Wartabone. Ministry of PPN/Bappenas initially plans to piloting an conservation agreement of sugar palm production between national park manager, agroforestry community group, and Forest Management Units through intensive group discussion. However, Ministry of PPN/Bappenas until now still has not been able to visit the site to initiate dialogue with local community. If this situation continues until end of the project, Ministry of PPN/Bappenas will only be able to assess the readiness of conservation agreement as one of the sustainable financing sources. Two new financing mechanisms have been set in place (the use of Surat Berharga Syariah Negara and mainstreaming protected areas issue into the national priority program), however the calculation of contribution from those two schemes is still ongoing.
During the project, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has completed a review of regulation framework to support the financing mechanism to protected areas (Ev13). A proposed business opportunity and financial analysis for each project priority landscape has also been finalized. In addition to that, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has formulated the design of Sustainable Financing Mechanism for Conservation Areas. The design has been publicly consulted and suggesting the institutional arrangement in conservation forest to achieve the sustainable financing (Ev4, Ev14, Ev15). The proposed institutional arrangement combines three types of institutional function: coordinator or policy maker, funding agency, and implementating unit.
In 2020, The Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is aiming to increase the effectiveness of sustainable financing through broader socialization. The methodology that is deployed is ADKAR (appreciation, desire, knowledge, ability, and reinforcement) for three mechanisms: Surat Berharga Syariah Negara, BLU (Badan Layanan Umum/Public Services Agency), and Trust Fund. Series of thematic FGDs to introduce and socialize various alternative schemes of protected areas financing has been done as well.
Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is actively encouraging the use of Surat Berharga Syariah Negara instruments so that it can finance the development of ecotourism infrastructure and wildlife breeding in conservation areas (Ev2). The utilization of Surat Berharga Syariah Negara for conservation activities has been initited since 2018 in 3 pilot areas (one of which is in Sulawesi Island), and keep increasing to 5 areas in 2019, and to 9 areas in 2020. In 2020, the utilization of Surat Berharga Syariah Negara has reached USD 8,8 million across protected areas in Indonesia. Planning and budgeting activity for utilization of Surat Berharga Syariah Negara for year 2021 is currently ongoing. This year, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas also initiates to develop a socioecological indicator to monitor and evaluate the effectiveness of Surat Berharga Syariah Negara as source of protected areas financing.
The Ministry of PPN/Bappenas has also raised the issue of ecotourism development and protection of endangered animals into national priority projects to get increased budget allocations for both issues. This is indicated by the many outputs of National Park Management activities that become national priority outputs.
Furthermore, the Ministry of PPN/Bappenas is currently examining the role/contribution of conservation to the national priorities as well as the Surat Berharga Syariah Negara that could provide at least USD 3 million per year for conservation areas and biodiversity management in Sulawesi. The roles of conservation have been reflected in the annual government work plan (Rencana Kerja Pemerintah/RKP) and the mid-term national development plan (Rencana Pembangunan Jangka Menengah Nasional/RPJMN).
By encouraging the utilization of SBSN and integrating the importance of protected areas into the national priority program, Ministry of PPN/Bappenas attempt to give benefit to as many stakeholders as possible. Hopefully it can stimulate the local economy as well as initiate partnership with local government, private sector, and community.
To conclude, component 2.3 is approximately 85% agains EOP target, it is due to the calculation of contribution from those two schemes is still underway.
As regards to the 10th Indicator: the METT value has increased in all project sites: 1) 77% in BNW NP; 2) 68% in Tangkoko Batuputih NR; 61% in Tangkoko Batuangus NR; 62% in Tangkoko Duasudara NR; 3) 73% in LL NP. As regards to the 11th Indicator: Threat Index was 31% in Bogani Nani Wartabone NP; 18% in Tangkoko NR; and 18% in Lore Lindu NP. As regards to the 12th Indicator: The value of Environmental Health Indicator reached 66% in BNW NP, 78% in Tangkoko NR, and 66% in LL NP. As regards to the 13th Indicator: In BNW NP: 1) the occupancy rate based on trap camera for the anoa and deer-pig subsequently is 32% and 36%; 2) The occupancy rate of the maleo birds couple in 3 locations throughout the years of 2016-2019, has significantly increased from 6.4% to 54.4%. In the Tangkoko Batuangas NR: 1) The Yaki SRAK document has been legalized in the year 2019; 2) Based on the monitoring and evaluation conducted in year 2019, four locations of active spawning of maleo birds have been found; 3) There has been found that the population density of Yaki reached 14.6 Yakis/km2 based on the survey done in 2019. In the area of LL NP: 1) In the year 2019 in the Cluster of CS-25 the rate of encounter with the anoa was 40 times; 2) In Q2 of year 2020 it is planned to conduct survey on the anoa in the Clusters of CS-18 and CS-5. Zero increase in net levels of active encroachment.
KPHK Tangkoko: The encroachment surrounding the area of KPHK Tangkoko covered approximately 970,80 ha (Map available).
As regards to the 14th Indicator: In BNW NP: 1) Joint area patrol by the community through RBM mechanism and Smart Patrol have been done in 11 resorts; 2) It has been stated in the CCA agreement by 17 groups in 15 villages to refrain from any encroaching activities; 3)Re-planting activities have been implemented by CCA groups with conservation partnership for ecosystem recovery. In Tangkoko NR: 1) With the support of the EPASS project, all of the CCAs have agreed to refrain from encroaching activities; 2) Awareness raising regarding border boundary has been conducted in the buffer zone of Tangkoko NR; 3) Planting on the border line has been done by CCA Madidir & Winesa; 4) Replanting the open areas has been done together with the local natural resources conservation agency (BKSDA) and the partners. In LL NP: 1) SMART Patrol has been conducted; 2) Has supported the recovery of the Dongi Dongi ecosystem; 3) Establishment of village conservation management unit, for which part of the activities is conducting joint patrol with the community of the National Park; 4)Reduce any activities related to encroachment by planting non-timber forest products in the traditional zones, Planting living boundary together with the CCAs of Doda Village and Lempe Village.
As regards to the 15th Indicator: Until Q2 of year 2020, there have been 46 agreement documents signed out of the 46 documents proposed. The funds has been disbursed in the amount of IDR3,345,813,124 for 42 signed documents, out of the total value for 46 documents in the amount of IDR6,227,218,648.
